In [[NEXTSTEP]], [[OPENSTEP]], their lineal descendants [[Mac OS X]], [[IOS (Apple)|iOS]], and in [[GNUstep]], a bundle is a [[directory (file systems)|directory]] that allows related resources such as an application's executable and its graphics to be grouped together, appearing as a single file to the user.
Examples include [[Application software|applications]], [[Application framework|frameworks]], and [[Plug-in (computing)|plugins]]. They are accessed with the <tt>NSBundle</tt> class in [[Cocoa (API)|Cocoa]], [[NEXTSTEP]] and [[GNUstep]]'s [[Foundation_Kit|Foundation]] frameworks, and with <tt>CFBundle</tt> in [[Core Foundation]].
A bundle usually contains one file representing executable code, and files that represent resources such as [[Interface Builder#Nib files|nibs]], images, sounds, and other media. On some other systems, such as [[Microsoft Windows]], these resources are usually included directly in the executable file itself at compile time. On older Macintoshes, a similar technique is used, where additional [[metadata]] can be added to a file's [[resource fork]]. The [[Finder (software)|Finder]] treats bundles, which can also be referred to as [[Package (Mac OS X)|packages]], as opaque files with no underlying structure.
The [[Uniform Type Identifier]] (UTI) for an Apple bundle is <tt>com.apple.bundle</tt>.<ref>{{cite web|title=System-Declared Uniform Type Identifiers|work=Uniform Type Identifiers Reference|url=http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Miscellaneous/Reference/UTIRef/Articles/System-DeclaredUniformTypeIdentifiers.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009259-SW1|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|accessdate=2011-03-16}}</ref>
Similar in concept are the [[Application Directory|application directories]] used in [[RISC OS]] and on the [[ROX Desktop]], and the [[RUNZ]] bundles in [[Super OS]].
==Mac OS X application bundles== Application bundles are directory hierarchies, with the top-level directory having a name that ends with a <tt>.app</tt> extension. In an application bundle, the first directory in the bundle underneath the top-level directory is usually named <tt>Contents</tt>. Within <tt>Contents</tt> there is usually another directory (called <tt>MacOS</tt> on Macs, or using the application's name on [[GNUstep]]), which contains the application's executable code. Within the <tt>Contents</tt> folder there is usually also a directory called <tt>Resources</tt>, which contains the resources of the application.
Among other things, the <tt>Resources</tt> folder contains localized versions of the application's [[Interface Builder|nib file]]s.
Other common subdirectories include <tt>Plugins</tt>, <tt>Frameworks</tt>, and <tt>Shared Frameworks</tt>. The <tt>Frameworks</tt> directory contains frameworks used by the application, and are used even if another version of the framework exists on the system. The <tt>Shared Frameworks</tt> directory contains frameworks that can be used both by the application that contains them, and other applications; they are used only if a newer version does not exist elsewhere on the system. <tt>Plugins</tt> contains extensible code used by the application.
==Mac OS X framework bundles== Mac OS X frameworks are also stored as bundles; the top-level directory of a framework bundle has a name that is the name of the framework followed by the extension <tt>.framework</tt>. In the top-level directory is a <tt>Versions</tt> directory, with subdirectories for one or more versions of the framework, each subdirectory containing the dynamic library code for the framework, in a file whose name is the same as the name of the framework, possibly with a <tt>Headers</tt> folder containing [[header file]]s for the framework, and other subfolders such as <tt>Resources</tt>. The <tt>Versions</tt> directory also contains a symbolic link <tt>Current</tt> to the directory for the current version of the framework. In the top-level directory are symbolic links to the contents of <tt>Versions/Current</tt>.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anatomy of Framework Bundles|url=http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/MacOSX/Conceptual/BPFrameworks/Concepts/FrameworkAnatomy.html|publisher=Apple Inc.|accessdate=2011-09-03}}</ref>.
==Mac OS X loadable bundles== Loadable bundles are bundles which contain code that can be loaded at runtime.<ref>[http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/LoadingCode/Concepts/AboutLoadableBundles.html Code Loading Programming Topics for Cocoa: About Loadable Bundles<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Loadable bundles usually have the extension <tt>.bundle</tt> and are most often used as [[plug-in (computing)|plug-ins]]. An example of an application that traditionally supports bundles is [[Apple Mail]].<ref>[http://www.tikouka.net/mailapp/ Apple Mail plug-ins and tools<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://hawkwings.net/plugins.htm Hawk Wings — Plug-ins for Apple Mail<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> On Mac OS X there is a way to load bundles even into applications that don't support them allowing for third party hacks for popular applications such as [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]].<ref>[http://pimpmysafari.com/plugins/ Pimp My Safari: plugins<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Other bundle formats== There are many third-party Mac OS X applications which utilize their own custom bundle format (e.g. [[CandyBar]]'s <tt>.iContainer</tt> bundles).
==.lproj== <!-- Merged from [[.lproj]] --> An '''.lproj''' file is a bundle that contains [[software localization|localization]] files for [[Mac OS X]] software. It typically contains the [[.nib]] files for a given language along with string files and images if need be (for example, [[ReadMe]] or license files). These localized files are used by install makers to customize install packages. They are also included into an application bundle.
